I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The regional knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help (i) strengthen 
teacher  quality  and  leadership  capacities  for  school  education  in  the  Philippines  through 
innovative  initiatives  for  teacher  professional  development  and  education  leadership;  and 
(ii) enable knowledge exchange with Bangladesh, Cambodia, and the Philippines on innovative 
approaches  for  improving  teacher  quality  and  effectiveness  through  partnerships  between 
government and civil society organizations (CSOs). 
 
2.  The TA is included in the 2019 results-based work plan of the Sustainable Development 
and Climate Change Department.1 It is aligned with (i) the country partnership strategy of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) for the Philippines, which focuses on reforms to increase school 
completion rates;2 (ii) the Secondary Education Support Program in the Philippines, funded by 
ADB;3 and (iii) the objectives of school education programs supported by ADB in Bangladesh and 
Cambodia.4 It also aligns with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and the operational priority on addressing 
remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, which includes education.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Asian countries such as Bangladesh, Cambodia, and the Philippines are reforming their 
educational systems to improve quality and increase student learning. The aim is to create a 
competitive workforce that can respond to the demands of fast-changing labor markets.6 The job 
markets of tomorrow require highly skilled workers. Capable and highly skilled teachers are crucial 
to creating a new generation of learners. However, in the Philippines, while enrollment has been 
increasing, quality remains a significant issue. A 2016 World Bank study showed that teachers’ 
content knowledge is weak, in-service teacher training (INSET) is inadequate, and student 
learning  remains  poor. 7  School  needs  and  teacher  specialization  and  deployment  are 
mismatched, and professional development is inadequate to deliver the recently mandated K to 
12  Program  (K–12) 8curriculum.  Countries  such  as  Bangladesh  and  Cambodia  also  face 
problems regarding the quality and skills of their teachers. Bangladesh faces challenges in the 
quality of learning and inadequate teacher capacity. Cambodia faces disparities in educational 
attainment and lack of qualified teachers, particularly in secondary schools. The ministries of 
education  in  Bangladesh,  Cambodia,  and  the  Philippines  are  partnering  with  CSOs  in 
implementing innovative approaches to teacher professional development to improve teaching

and learning. Teach for All (TFA), a global CSO, has been implementing a unique approach to 
attract talented and qualified graduates to improve the quality and impact of teaching. It is part of 
a global CSO network of 48 independent country organizations with a shared vision of expanding 
educational  opportunities.  With  a  common  approach  of  selecting  young  high-performing 
graduates and placing them as teachers with intensive and contextual teacher training, the 
country organizations affiliated with TFA have contributed to augmenting high-quality teacher 
resources in poor and remote schools. In the Philippines, Teach for the Philippines (TFP) has 
been a partner of the Department of Education (DepEd) in addressing teacher shortage. TFP has 
a rigorous selection process to recruit qualified and motivated college graduates to be teachers. 
Candidates  undergo  500  hours  of  intensive  training  in  pedagogy  before  being  placed  in 
government schools in collaboration with DepEd to alleviate teacher constraints. This partnership 
has increased high-quality teacher resources in Grades 1-6 in underprivileged elementary schools. 
Unique to the Philippines, TFP has nurtured teachers to transition to being “ambassadors9” to 
support education policy reform. The TA will engage TFP through direct contracting to scale up 
its interventions in Philippine schools by collaborating closely with DepEd. 
 
4.  It will build on TFP’s work and achievements since its evolution from a predecessor CSO 
(Sa Aklat Sisikat Foundation) to TFP in 2012. It will also build on previous TA supported by ADB 
with TFP, which adapted the TFA model to the Philippines. 10 The activities proposed in this TA 
represent a natural continuation and expansion of interventions undertaken through partnership 
between ADB, TFP, and DepEd to address teacher shortages and lack of adequate teacher 
capacities for interactive classroom practices. An impact evaluation by the Abdul Latif Jameel 
Poverty Action Lab, a global research center working to reduce poverty by ensuring that policy is 
informed by scientific evidence, confirmed the positive effect of the previous TA. Lessons learned, 
among others, include (i) the recognition that capacitating public school teachers in software and 
information and communication technology tools may require a back-to-basics approach and in-
depth training;  (ii)  considering  a  series  of  one-on-one meetings for  the  design  of steering 
committees instead of a single group format; and (iii) the value of developing an implementation 
arrangement that works directly with TFP in managing consultants, which promoted ownership 
and prompt reporting of activities under the TA. The previous TA’s completion report recommends 
expanding TFP training to public school teachers for scale and sustainability. 11 The new TA will 
help to extend teacher training resources to more government teachers and to develop new 
teacher training modules for higher grades (7–10). 
   
5.  In addition to ensuring cognitive skills, students need to develop soft or employability skills. 
Soft skills are part of the 21st century skills the Philippines has incorporated into the K–12 
curriculum. The TA will assess and document unique and country-specific efforts of the TFA 
network in the three countries covered by the TA to enhance teacher competencies in preparing 
students for jobs of the future.  
 
6.  Similar to TFP, Teach for Bangladesh and Teach for Cambodia complement efforts of the 
respective governments in teacher training. The TA will support the development of a knowledge 
product  that  documents  country-specific  approaches  in  Bangladesh,  Cambodia,  and  the 
Philippines;  and  emerging  lessons  and  promising  approaches that  could  be  used  in  other

7.  The TA will help to remedy the lack of adequate teacher capacities in poor government 
schools by creating new pedagogical models. It will support the expansion of TFP good practices 
and help to capture tacit knowledge by documenting the experience of Teach for Bangladesh and 
Teach for Cambodia in teacher professional development to improve teaching and learning. 
Bangladesh and Cambodia exemplify the challenges faced by developing countries in improving 
the quality and performance of the teaching force. The TA will complement ongoing  ADB 
operations in support of nationwide reforms to school education in these countries and help 
strengthen government–CSO partnerships to improve quality. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: quality of teaching and learning in intervention 
schools improved.12 The TA will have the following outcome: instructional practice and leadership 
skills in intervention schools improved.13 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Teacher professional development for primary and junior secondary 
education in  government  schools  enhanced. This  will  support  the development  of  new 
curricula and training material for in-service professional development of teachers, covering 
100 TFP teachers and 1,000 government teachers, through DepEd’s INSET in the Philippines. 
Training materials developed under this TA will be available in an open domain. This will benefit 
15,000 students in primary and secondary needy public schools in the Philippines.  
 
10.  Output 2: Leadership skills for basic education strengthened. This will help to develop 
a customized training program for public officials and TFP teachers seeking to transition from 
teaching to public service roles in the Philippines. This leadership training program will also 
facilitate education sector reforms. The TA will finance the development of curricula, training 
material, and training of trainers, designed in partnership with a leading management institution. 
A certificate program on leadership and change management will be developed, and this training 
will benefit 30 public officials and 30 TFP ambassadors to facilitate leadership for implementing 
K–12 reforms in the Philippines, particularly to improve quality. 
 
11.  Output 3: Knowledge sharing and dissemination facilitated. The output will support 
sharing of key lessons and successful approaches in a two-pronged way in ADB’s developing 
member countries. First, it will support knowledge sharing through DepEd’s INSET training and 
learning circles, reaching a larger group of government teachers. Second, a regional workshop 
will present a knowledge product from Bangladesh, Cambodia, and the Philippines to enable 
pooling of knowledge on teacher professional development and teacher effectiveness. Innovative 
approaches to teacher professional development through CSOs in these three countries will be

on how to improve the capacity of teachers and government officials. These will be documented 
in the planned knowledge product and online knowledge resources. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6: $165,000 and TASF-other sources: $585,000). The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA and will be the executing and implementing agencies. TFP will 
be engaged as a consultant through direct contracting in accordance with the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) to deliver the outputs. A steering committee, with 
representation from TFP and DepEd, will meet annually to review implementation progress. The 
TA will be monitored by ADB’s Education Sector Group Secretariat in coordination with the 
respective regional departments. Regular TA review missions will be fielded to monitor progress. 
 
14.  A direct contract is envisaged with TFP since it is in a unique position to undertake this TA 
as the continuation of a partnership between TFP–ADB and TFP–DepEd in the following ways: 
(i) placing TFP teachers in needy government schools facing teacher shortages; (ii) expanding 
teacher training beyond the primary grades to junior secondary grades at the request of DepEd; 
and (iii) extending the methodology for teacher professional development to more than 1,000 
government teachers and to DepEd’s INSET for wider application of successful practices. As a 
trusted  CSO,  TFP  will  collaborate  with  DepEd  to  advance  initiatives  to  improve  teacher 
professional development and in-school support to enhance the learning environment. TFP will 
also enable the sharing of country-specific experiences in Bangladesh, Cambodia, and the 
Philippines. All three countries have TFA initiatives, which is a unique worldwide effort based on 
a common model for improving teacher resources in poor public schools. No other global CSO 
network comparable with TFA is working on issues of teacher professional development and 
practice. The TA will enable ADB to apply innovative CSO-led approaches to improve classroom 
teaching and learning to large-scale education sector programs financed through ADB loans. 
 
15.  TFP will carry out procurement in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy and its 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. TFP will be engaged for 
the TA using direct contracting. This is in line with the provisions for a direct contract, as the 
consulting services of TFP represent a natural continuation of work carried out in the previous TA 
(para. 14). TFP will oversee day-to-day implementation, including procurement, disbursement, 
reporting, and information collection. TFP will procure goods through request for quotations. 
Limited office equipment, data management tools, and software licenses may be purchased. All 
equipment will be procured by TFP and will be turned over to DepEd at the end of the TA.

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy

320 person-months of services (20 international and 300 national) by TFP, which will be engaged 
by ADB through direct contracting. Output-based and/or lump-sum contracts will be considered 
for consulting services, where appropriate, with the concurrence of ADB’s Procurement, Portfolio 
and Financial Management Department. 
 
18.  Social media and websites. The TA will support the creation of online resources for 
teacher professional development, aligned to the needs of the K–12 program of the Philippines. 
While these will be mainly developed and maintained by TFP, ADB’s Social Media Guidelines 
and branding15 will be shared for TFP’s reference. Such online resources will be made publicly 
available for use of all DepEd teachers. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
the Strengthening Human Resources and Leadership for Education, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.   Teacher professional development for primary and junior secondary education in government schools 
      enhanced 
1.1 Develop 500-hour blended learning teacher professional development curricula for about 100 TFP teachers and 
      1,000 public school teachers, including digital training material, for pre- and in-service professional development 
      of teachers by Q4 2019. 
1.2 Complete 100-hour training of trainers for the delivery of teachers’ pre- and in-service professional development 
by Q2 2020. 
1.3 Deliver pre- and in-service professional development program to 1,000 public school teachers as well as 
      100 TFP teachers by Q4 2021. 
1.4 Conduct classroom observation evaluation with Department of Education’s competency-based standards to 
      100% of teachers by Q4 2021, with 70% of teachers attaining “proficient” level. 
1.5 Share training material via the Department of Education Learning Portal by Q4 2021. 
 
2.   Leadership skills for basic education strengthened 
2.1 Develop a new training program for public teachers and/or administrators and TFP ambassadors, including 
online version by Q1 2020. 
2.2 Conduct leadership training for TFP ambassadors and public officials by Q1 2021. 
 
3.   Knowledge sharing and dissemination facilitated 
3.1 Prepare one knowledge product on TFP and TFA approaches and the impact on beneficiaries in two TFA 
      members and ADB DMCs by Q2 2021. 
3.2 Organize one regional workshop to share TFP’s experience, lessons learned, and outcomes with ADB DMC 
      officials and ADB staff by Q2 2021.

Conduct regular meetings with TFP to make the TA effective and monitor progress based on milestones.
